repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
Here I was forced to use `cython.declare()`. Annotating two lines
```python
    shape: Py_ssize_t[2]
    strides: Py_ssize_t[2]
```
 gives following error during compiing:
```

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
        buffer.itemsize = itemsize
        buffer.len = self.v.size() * itemsize   # product(shape) * itemsize
        buffer.ndim = 2
        buffer.obj = self
        buffer.readonly = 0
        buffer.shape = self.shape
                           ^
------------------------------------------------------------

matrix_with_buffer.py:44:27: Cannot convert Python object to 'Py_ssize_t *'

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
        buffer.len = self.v.size() * itemsize   # product(shape) * itemsize
        buffer.ndim = 2
        buffer.obj = self
        buffer.readonly = 0
        buffer.shape = self.shape
        buffer.strides = self.strides
                             ^
------------------------------------------------------------

matrix_with_buffer.py:45:29: Cannot convert Python object to 'Py_ssize_t *'
```

I suppose it is a bug. If confirmed I can create bug for that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+# distutils: language = c++
+from cython.cimports.cpython import Py_buffer
+from cython.cimports.libcpp.vector import vector
+
+@cython.cclass
+class Matrix:
+    ncols: cython.Py_ssize_t
+    shape = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])
+    strides = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])

comment_data.body: `shape: cython.Py_ssize_t[2]` doesn't work? (I.e. from the Cython module)

comment_data.body:
> What I see as a pain in pure python mode is that it does not raise error that Py_ssize_t is not declared but it just fallbacks to object instead

I'm not sure about this. There's a lot of annotations that we don't understand (e.g. much of the `typing` module, pretty much any non-extension type class). The two things I could see about `Py_ssize_t` that could make it sensible to raise a warning are: it matches a C type, and Cython doesn't know where the name comes from (i.e. it isn't imported from anywhere). So we probably could do better about warning about annotations that Cython doesn't understand, but it shouldn't be all of them.

One of the reasons I proposed a "full" annotation typing mode (https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4883) is that it could let us assume that every annotation is intended for Cython and actually generate errors if it doesn't understand them. I'm not sure my PR does that yet though.

> it is funny that `declare()` is fine with just Py_ssize_t

I think there was some debate about this too (https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4882). My opinion was that `declare` is definitely intended to be read by Cython; an annotation might not be.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+# distutils: language = c++
+from cython.cimports.cpython import Py_buffer
+from cython.cimports.libcpp.vector import vector
+
+@cython.cclass
+class Matrix:
+    ncols: cython.Py_ssize_t
+    shape = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])
+    strides = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])

comment_data.body:
But it's tricky - there's basically two sets of people:

1. people like you who want to write *Cython* code but using annotations instead of `cdef`.
2. people who want to compile annotated Python code and have Cython do something sensible where it can.

and that's kind of why I wanted to have "full" and "safe" `annotation_typing` modes - to keep both groups happy!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+# distutils: language = c++
+from cython.cimports.cpython import Py_buffer
+from cython.cimports.libcpp.vector import vector
+
+@cython.cclass
+class Matrix:
+    ncols: cython.Py_ssize_t
+    shape = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])
+    strides = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])

comment_data.body: Hmm my humble opinion is that the problem can be reduced to following: The code contains symbol (`Py_ssize_t`) which is not declared/imported anywhere - so cython should raise an error. Cython does not need to understand annotation but it should at least check if the symbols in annotation were declared somewhere or imported. It has nothing with understanding of annotations but "just" checking that symbols were declared properly. Cython can check symbols if are defined correctly and still ignore annotations since it cannot evaluate it properly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+# distutils: language = c++
+from cython.cimports.cpython import Py_buffer

+class Matrix:
+    ncols: cython.Py_ssize_t
+    shape = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])
+    strides = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t[2])

commit.message: Docs: Migrate buffer userguide to pure python

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Docs: Migrate buffer userguide to pure python
